title: The Arrest and Trial of Jesus
shortSummary: John 18 details the arrest of Jesus in the Garden of Gethsemane, Peter’s denial, and Jesus’ initial trial before Jewish and Roman authorities. This chapter highlights Jesus’ willing submission to suffering and the fulfillment of prophecy, setting the stage for His crucifixion.
timeline: c. AD 30 - The Passion Week, just before the crucifixion of Jesus

keyCharacters.name: Jesus
keyCharacters.description: The Son of God who willingly submits to arrest and trial, demonstrating His obedience to the Father’s will.

keyCharacters.name: Simon Peter
keyCharacters.description: One of Jesus’ closest disciples who impulsively defends Jesus but later denies Him three times.

keyCharacters.name: Judas Iscariot
keyCharacters.description: The disciple who betrays Jesus by leading the arresting party to Him.

keyCharacters.name: Caiaphas
keyCharacters.description: The high priest who orchestrates the plot to have Jesus put to death.

keyCharacters.name: Pontius Pilate
keyCharacters.description: The Roman governor who questions Jesus and ultimately authorizes His crucifixion despite finding no fault in Him.

definitions.definition: A small stream east of Jerusalem near the Garden of Gethsemane, where Jesus was arrested.
Jesus’ declaration using the divine name, causing those who came to arrest Him to fall back, showing His divine authority.
The Jewish festival commemorating Israel’s deliverance from Egypt, during which Jesus was arrested and crucified.
The servant of the high priest whose ear was cut off by Peter during Jesus’ arrest.

outline.heading: Jesus’ Arrest in the Garden
outline.description: Jesus is betrayed by Judas and arrested by a band of soldiers. Jesus identifies Himself with authority, fulfilling prophecy and demonstrating His control over the events.

outline.heading: Peter’s Denial
outline.description: Peter follows Jesus to the high priest’s house but denies knowing Him three times, fulfilling Jesus’ earlier prediction and illustrating human weakness.

outline.heading: Jesus Before Pilate
outline.description: Jesus is brought before the Roman governor Pilate, who questions Him about His kingship. Despite finding no fault, Pilate yields to the crowd’s demand to release Barabbas instead of Jesus.

application: Trust in Jesus’ sovereign control even in times of trial and uncertainty, knowing He fulfills God’s plan.
Recognize the danger of denying Christ in difficult moments and seek God’s strength to stand firm in faith.
Respond to opposition with humility and obedience, following Jesus’ example of submission to the Father’s will.
Pray for courage and wisdom to witness boldly about Christ, even when facing persecution or rejection.

keyVerses.text: As soon then as he had said unto them, I am he, they went backward, and fell to the ground.
keyVerses.significance: This verse reveals Jesus’ divine authority and the power of His identity as the Son of God.

keyVerses.text: Then said Jesus unto Peter, Put up thy sword into the sheath: the cup which my Father hath given me, shall I not drink it?
keyVerses.significance: Jesus teaches submission to God’s will, emphasizing the necessity of His suffering for redemption.

keyVerses.text: Pilate therefore said unto him, Art thou a king then? Jesus answered, Thou sayest that I am a king. To this end was I born, and for this cause came I into the world, that I should bear witness unto the truth. Every one that is of the truth heareth my voice.
keyVerses.significance: Jesus declares His kingship and mission to testify to the truth, inviting all who belong to truth to follow Him.

keyVerses.text: But ye have a custom, that I should release unto you one at the passover: will ye therefore that I release unto you the King of the Jews?
keyVerses.significance: Pilate’s offer highlights the rejection of Jesus by the people despite His innocence, fulfilling God’s redemptive plan.
